# Public Prosecutor _v_ K Manirasan  

### \[2022\] SGDC 235

<table id="info-table"><tbody><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Case Number</td><td class="txt-body">District Arrest Case No 907566-2021, Magistrate's Appeal No 9185-2022-01</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Decision Date</td><td class="txt-body">04 October 2022</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Tribunal/Court</td><td class="txt-body">District Court</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Coram</td><td class="txt-body">Salina Bte Ishak</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Counsel Name(s)</td><td class="txt-body">Theong Li Han (Attorney-General's Chambers) for the Prosecution; Kanagavijayan Nadarajan (Kana &amp; Co) and Amolat Singh (Amolat &amp; Partners) for the accused.</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Parties</td><td class="txt-body">Public Prosecutor — K Manirasan</td></tr></tbody></table>

Criminal Procedure and Sentencing – Statutory Offences – Road Traffic Act – Driving without due care and attention and causing grievous hurt

\[LawNet Editorial Note: An appeal to this decision has been filed in MA 9185/2022/01.\]

4 October 2022

### District Judge Salina Bte Ishak:

## Background

1       The accused, Mr K Manirasan, a 56-year-old male Singapore citizen was first charged on 28 April 2021 for the following offence:

Charge (Amended)

> are charged that you, on 1 August 2020, at about 12.52 am, along Hougang Avenue 4 towards the direction of Upper Serangoon Road, Singapore, did drive motorcar bearing registration number SJX1672J without due care and attention, to wit, you failed to keep a proper lookout when turning right at the signalised junction of Hougang Avenue 8, which resulted in a collision with the motorcycle bearing registration number JSS4157 which was travelling straight from the opposite direction and had the right of way, thereby causing grievous hurt to V Krisnarao Venkatesan, the rider of the said motorcycle, to wit, multiple fractures, a right open subtalar dislocation and right ankle degloving injury, and you have thereby committed an offence under s 65(1)(a), punishable under s 65(3)(a) read with s 65(6)(d) of the Road Traffic Act (Cap 276, 2004 Rev Ed).

2       On 23 August 2022, after multiple adjournments for directions to be obtained, for representations to be considered and for Criminal Case Management System (CCMS) conferences with the Prosecution to be convened, the accused finally pleaded guilty to the charge and admitted to the Statement of Facts without any qualification.

3       The matter was adjourned to 6 September 2022 for his Defence Counsel, Mr Kanagavijayan Nadarajan of Kana & Co to prepare the plea in mitigation as well as the submissions on sentence. After carefully considering the Prosecution’s address on sentence, the Defence’s plea in mitigation as well as the sentencing submissions, I sentenced the accused to four weeks’ imprisonment and disqualified him from holding or obtaining all classes of driving licences for a period of five years with effect from the date of release. The accused then sought a deferment of his sentence until 3 October 2022 for him to make the necessary arrangements and to inform his employer of his sentence.

4       On 19 September 2022, the accused being dissatisfied with my decision filed his Notice of Appeal against my sentence through his new Counsel, Mr Amolat Singh of Amolat & Partners. On 20 September 2022, at a post-sentence mention, I revoked his agency bail and offered bail pending appeal. He is presently on bail pending the hearing of his appeal.

5       Having set out the background for the present case, I now provide the reasons for my decision.

## Salient Facts

6       The accused was the driver of the motorcar bearing registration number SJX1672J (“the car”). The victim is V Krisnarao Venkatesan, a 34-year-old male Malaysian. At the material time, the victim was the rider of the motorcycle bearing registration number JSS4157 (“the motorcycle”).

7       On 1 August 2020, at about 12.52am, the accused was driving the car along Hougang Avenue 4 towards the direction of Upper Serangoon Road, Singapore. The victim was riding the motorcycle along Hougang Avenue 8 in the opposite direction. While at the signalised junction of Hougang Avenue 8, the accused failed to keep a proper lookout and executed a right turn when the traffic light was green only. The victim had the right of way at the material time. As a result, the left side of the car collided with the motorcycle. The impact of the collision caused the victim to be flung over the car. The victim landed a short distance away. The collision was captured by the in-car camera of a witness whose car had stopped at the junction.

8       The victim was conveyed by ambulance to Tan Tock Seng Hospital (“TTSH”) after the accident. According to the medical report prepared by Dr Daniel Hap dated 9 December 2020, the victim sustained the following injuries:

> (a)     right femur shaft open fracture;

> (b)     right lateral femur condyle avulsion fracture;

> (c)     right distal fibula and calcaneal fractures;

> (d)     right open subtalar dislocation;

> (e)     right cuboid and 2nd metatarsal base fracture;

> (f)     right ankle degloving injury; and

> (g)     right cervical-7 transverse process fracture.

9       An MRI scan was performed, which revealed an interspinous ligament sprain injury and an undisplaced fracture of the left C7 transverse process with mild stress reaction changes at endplates of C5 to C6. As a result of his injuries, the victim underwent an emergency surgery on 1 August 2020, the day of admission. During his stay at the hospital, the victim further underwent multiple surgeries (4 August 2020 – wound debridement of right foot wound, 12 August 2020 – right foot wound debridement and negative pressure dressing, and 15 August 2020 – right foot wound debridement and application of external ring fixator). The victim was hospitalized for 20 days from 1 August 2020 to 21 August 2020 and given 35 days of hospitalisation leave from 1 August 2020 to 4 September 2020. After his discharge from TTSH, the victim returned to Malaysia for medical follow up.

10     As a result of the accident, the right portion of the motorcycle was damaged. As for the car, the right front portion was damaged.

11     At the time of the accident, the weather was clear, road surface dry, visibility clear, and traffic flow light. Neither the car nor the motorcycle had any mechanical fault.

12     By virtue of the foregoing, the accused did drive the car without due care and attention, thus causing grievous hurt to the victim. The accused has thus committed an offence under s 65(1)(_a_), punishable under s 65(3)(_a_) read with s 65(6)(_d_) of the Road Traffic Act (“RTA”).

## Sentencing

## Prescribed Penalty

13     The prescribed penalty for an offence under s 65(1)(_b_) and punishable ss 65(3)(_a_) read with 65(6)(_d_) of the RTA is fine not exceeding $5,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or to both. In addition, the offender is liable to a mandatory disqualification order for all classes of vehicles for at least five years.

## Antecedents

14     The accused has no prior convictions.

## Prosecution’s Submissions on Sentence

15     The Prosecution had sought a sentence of between one to two months’ imprisonment as well as the mandatory disqualification period of five years. It was submitted that the High Court has set out the sentencing framework in respect of offences punishable under s 65(3)(_a_) of the RTA in _Sue Chang (Xu Zheng) v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[2022\] SGHC 176</span> (“_Sue Chang_”).

16     It was the Prosecution’s position that in applying the sentencing framework, the first step was for the court is to have regard to the level of harm and the degree of culpability present in each case to determine where the starting point is within this matrix. In the present case, it was submitted that the level of harm was moderate while the accused’s degree of culpability was low.

17     It was the Prosecution’s case that the level of harm was pitched at moderate given that the victim had suffered multiple fractures requiring multiple surgical intervention. The victim was given a total of 35 days of hospitalisation leave. It was submitted that in the present case there were no specific culpability-enhancing factors. Accordingly, it was further submitted that based on the moderate level of harm and the low degree of culpability, based on the sentencing matrix in _Sue Chang_, the appropriate starting point is a fine and up to four months’ imprisonment. Given the seriousness of the victim's injuries, it was the Prosecution’s position that the custodial threshold has been crossed.

18     The next step was to make the adjustments to the starting point to take into account the offender-specific factors and the relevant one was his plea of guilt. Taking this into account, the Prosecution submitted that a custodial sentence of one to two months would be appropriate.

19     For completeness, it was highlighted that the victim was charged for drink driving. On 9 November 2021, he was fined $2,000 and disqualified from driving all classes of vehicle for a period of two years.

## Mitigation

20     In his written plea in mitigation, the Defence had set out the accused’s personal background as well as the circumstances that led to the commission of the offence. The Defence sought the imposition of the maximum fine of $5,000 and disqualification for five years. In essence, it was the Defence’s position that the accused was not fully culpable for the incident and that the victim should take some blame for speeding and drink driving at the material time.

21     At the material time, the accused was sending his son to a coffeeshop to meet his friend. The accused had stopped at the signalised junction of Hougang Avenue 4 and Hougang Avenue 8. He had waited for the vehicles coming from the direction of Upper Serangoon Road to clear. After the two vehicles ahead of him had make the successive right turn, the accused proceeded to make his right turn into Hougang Avenue 8. According to the Defence, it was at this time that the victim came at an extremely fast speed and collided into the front right bumper of the accused’s vehicle. The accused stopped his car and both he and his son rendered assistance to the victim. He did not leave the scene until the ambulance and the police arrived. He had also assisted the police in their investigations.

22     According to the Defence, the accused has driving licences for Class 2B, 2A and 3. Until the present incident, he was never involved in any serious accident. Until 1 August 2020, he had a relatively clean driving record. The accused was deeply remorseful for the accident.

23     It was submitted that the victim was culpable as he was drink driving and speeding at the material time. His level of alcohol was 101 milligrammes per 100 millilitres of blood. According to the Defence, the footage clearly showed that the victim was going at a high speed as shown by the impact of the accident. It was the Defence’s position that had the victim not been drinking and driving or speeding, he would have stopped in time to avoid the incident. In the alternative, he would have stopped, slowed down or swerved to manage or control his motorcycle to avoid the said collision. The Defence was unsure if the victim had switched on his headlights at the material time.

#### Application of the Sue Chang framework

24     Although the Defence agreed with the Prosecution that the level of harm was moderate, it was the Defence’s position that it was at the lower end of moderate. It was also agreed that the victim sustained seven fractures as recorded in the TTSH medical report. It was submitted that it was uncertain if the injuries were more of a permanent nature as the victim had returned to Malaysia for further follow-up. In terms of culpability, it was submitted that it was at a low level of carelessness. The accused admitted that he failed to give way when the accused had right of way.

25     It was further submitted that the starting point under moderate level of harm and low culpability is a fine and up to four months’ imprisonment. In terms of the third and the fourth step of the sentencing approach, adjustments can be made to the starting point by considering the following factors:

> (a)     the accused had pleaded guilty to the charge;

> (b)     the accused has spotted the vehicle immediately after the accident and his son rendered assistance to the victim as the accused was still in a daze;

> (c)     the accused had voluntarily provided to the police the in-car footage from another driver who was at the scene;

> (d)     the accused through his son had kept in touch with the victim and he had wanted to visit him at the hospital as a sign of his remorse;

> (e)     the victim was drink driving and speeding at the material time. Had he not done so, he could have stopped in time to avoid the said collision. Alternatively, he could have been able to stop, slow down or swerve so as to manage or control his vehicle to avoid the collision and

> (f)     if the victim had switched on his headlights.

26     The Defence urged the court to impose the maximum fine and a disqualification for five years as this would serve as a sufficiently strong deterrence to the accused.

## Prosecution’s Reply

27     In response to the Defence’s submission that the level of harm should fall at the lower end of moderate, firstly it was the Prosecution’s position that there was no basis to draw such a distinction based on the definition of moderate harm as set out in _Sue Chang_. In _Sue Chang_ at \[87(b)\] which defines moderate harm, it is stated: the injuries are of a more permanent nature and/or involve more complex fractures/dislocation which necessitate some surgical procedures with a moderate period of hospitalisation and/or medical leave. There is no conjunctive requirement that injuries must be of more permanent nature. It was the Prosecution’s position that just based on the number of fractures and the surgical procedures required to manage the injuries, the harm in the present case fell squarely within the moderate level.

28     Secondly, it was further submitted that the fact that the accused had stopped after the accident ought to be a neutral point as the accused is in fact under a duty to stop after the accident.

29     Thirdly, in relation to the Defence’s position that the victim was drink driving and speeding, it was the Prosecution’s position it was speculative to state that the accident could have been avoided if the victim had not been drink driving.

30     It was the Prosecution’s case that a sentence of one to two months’ imprisonment and the minimum disqualification period of five years would be appropriate.

## Sentencing considerations

### S 65(1) of the RTA

31     The present offence under s 65(1) of the RTA was enacted on 1 November 2019, following the passing of the Road Traffic (Amendment) Act 2019 (Act 19 of 2019). S 65(1) of the RTA encapsulates the primary offence of driving without due care or reasonable consideration for other persons using the road. The subsequent subsections from ss 65(2) to 65(4) are the penalty prescribing provisions, each tiered according to the degree of hurt caused and for s 65(5), for any other case of non-personal injury or potential harm.

#### Sentencing approach

32     In the present case, I was bound by the sentencing framework prescribed by Vincent Hoong J (“Hoong J”) in _Sue Chang (Xu Zheng) v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[2022\] SGHC 176</span> (“Sue Chang”) for offences of driving without due care and attention and causing grievous hurt. The sentencing framework for offences under section 65(3)(_a_) of the RTA where the offender has claimed trial is set out below:

![](data:image;base64,)

33     In _Sue Chang_, Hoong J made to two key observations at \[38\] to \[40\] in relation to the RTA amendments in the context of careless or inconsiderate driving. Firstly, as observed by Sundaresh Menon CJ (“Menon CJ”) in _Wu Zhi Yong v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[2021\] SGHC 261</span> (“_Wu Zhi Yong_”) at \[15\] (albeit in the related context of s 64 of the RTA), the Amendment Act envisaged a new scheme of penalties for careless or inconsiderate driving in a tiered structure calibrated according to the degree of hurt caused. This is codified in the RTA as ss 65(2) to 65(5). The maximum punishments which may be imposed for each category of harm increase concomitantly with the seriousness of the harm caused; this translates into wider ranges of punishments where more serious harm is occasioned. For instance, where death is caused, s 65(2)(_a_) provides that a first-time offender is liable to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years or to both. In contrast, the residual category (where no actual physical harm is caused, but which includes cases of non-personal injury or potential harm) captured in s 65(5)(_a_) provides that a first-time offender is liable to a fine not exceeding $1,500 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months or to both. By tiering the punishment provisions in accordance with the type of harm suffered, Parliament has given clear expression to the need to give explicit consideration to the outcomes that result from instances of careless or inconsiderate driving. This is a stark departure from the structure of s 65 of the pre-2019 RTA, where there was a single range of punishment with no differentiation based on the type and/or degree of harm caused.

34     Secondly, while Parliament has retained the distinction between reckless or dangerous driving under s 64 of the RTA and careless or inconsiderate driving under s 65 of the RTA, this distinction has been made more pronounced through the refining of the punishment provisions. These two provisions reflect the differing circumstances under which an irresponsible driving offence can occur. As can be seen from the Second Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Josephine Teo’s speech at \[36\], the former offence is regarded as being more serious than the latter, reflecting primarily the differing levels of culpability of the offenders. Accordingly, the current architecture of the RTA concerning irresponsible driving offences tiers the punishment provisions according to both harm and culpability, not dissimilar to the Penal Code.

35     At \[65\] of his judgment, Justice Hoong opined that the most suitable sentencing approach to adopt in respect of offences under s 65(3)(_a_) of the RTA is the two-stage, five-step sentencing framework laid down by Menon CJ in _Logachev Vladislav v PP_ <span class="citation">\[2018\] 4 SLR 609</span> at \[75\](“_Logachev_\-hybrid approach”). At \[84\] to \[108\] of his judgment, Hoong J had set out the five steps to be taken namely:

> (a)     The first step is to identify the level of harm caused by the offence and the level of culpability of the offender. The harm caused by the offence may be categorised into three levels of increasing severity: low, moderate and serious. Likewise, the offender’s culpability may be categorised into three levels: low, moderate and high. The non-exhaustive list of factors within the broad categories of harm and culpability which fashion the two axes of the matrix are:

>> **_1) Factors going to harm_**

>> The degree of harm caused would generally refer to the nature and degree of the grievous bodily injury caused to the victim(s): see _Tang Ling Lee_ v PP <span class="citation">\[2018\] 4 SLR 813</span> at \[25\] (“_Tang Ling Lee_”). The levels of harm can be divided based on the severity of the grievous hurt suffered as follows:

>>> (i)        _Low_: The hurt caused can be managed with conservative treatment, with no or short periods of hospitalisation and/or medical leave. The harm occasioned would typically involve minor fractures/dislocation at less vulnerable parts of the body.

>>> (ii)        _Moderate_: The injuries are of a more permanent nature and/or involve more complex fractures/dislocation which necessitate some surgical procedures with a moderate period of hospitalisation and/or medical leave.

>>> (iii)        _Serious_: The injuries are of a very serious or permanent nature and/or necessitate significant surgical procedures. The victim’s daily living is usually permanently and severely affected. This includes injuries resulting in loss of limb, sight, hearing, member or other major bodily functions or paralysis.

>> In addition, there are two other factors which may contribute to the severity of the harm caused, namely: (a) property damage; and (b) potential harm. These factors are to be considered in tandem with the above descriptions of each level of harm.

>> **_2) Factors going to culpability_**

>> This can be measured based on the following factors:

>>> (a)       Circumstances which required the offender to exercise extra care or consideration. Some examples of these circumstances include where the offender drives: (i) within a school or residential zone; (ii) a heavy vehicle that is more difficult to control and requires a quicker reaction time; or (iii) in poor road conditions (_eg_ heavy rain or heavy traffic);

>>> (b)       The manner of driving. Under this factor, it is apposite to consider any dangerous driving behaviour exhibited by the offender. This would include, for example, driving against the flow of traffic, speeding, sleepy driving, drink-driving, driving while under the influence of drugs, driving while using a mobile phone, flouting traffic rules, or “hell-riding” situations: see _Tang Ling Lee_ at \[28\]. In addition, considerations pertaining to the duration of the offender’s inattention (_eg_ momentary or prolonged/sustained), the avoidability of the offender’s distraction or the reasonableness of the offender’s misjudgment are also relevant;

>>> (c)       The offender’s conduct following the offence. An offender’s conduct that is “belligerent or violent” upon arrest would constitute an aggravating factor: see _Edwin s/o Suse Nathen v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[2013\] 4 SLR 1139</span> (“_Suse Nathen_”) at \[32\]. Where the offender fails to stop in an attempt to evade arrest or to avoid apprehension by the authorities, this should also weigh against him: see _Public Prosecutor v Lee Meng Soon_ <span class="citation">\[2007\] 4 SLR(R) 240</span> at \[33\].

> (b)     The second step is to identify the applicable indicative sentencing range in the sentencing matrix. Any term of imprisonment imposed may be accompanied by a fine of up to $5,000, if appropriate as this is explicitly provided for in s 65(3)(_a_) of the RTA. The sentencing judge should be alive to possibility of imposing such a combination of punishments in order to properly take into account the full sentencing range prescribed by Parliament. Hoong J opined that Parliament has stressed the importance of both harm and culpability and did not suggest that one factor should be given more weight in the sentencing analysis than the other. He emphasized that the proposed sentencing framework and the corresponding indicative ranges set out above are concerned solely with section 65(3)(a) of the RTA.

> (c)     The third step is to identify the appropriate starting point within the indicative sentencing range. This is to be informed by the level of harm caused by the offence and the level of the offender’s culpability.

> (d)     The fourth step is to make adjustments to the starting point where necessary to take into account the offender-specific aggravating and mitigating factors: see _Ng Kean Meng Terence v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[2017\] 2 SLR 449</span> (“Terence Ng”) at \[62\]-\[71\].

> (e)     The fifth step is to make further adjustments to take into account the totality principle. This step is relevant only where an offender is faced with multiple charges. It requires the court to consider the need to make further adjustments to the individual sentences for each charge to take into account the totality principle. The totality principle has been expressed in _Mohamed Shouffee bin Adam v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[2014\] 2 SLR 998</span> at \[54\] and \[57\] as comprising two limbs. The first limb examines whether the aggregate sentence is substantially above the normal level of sentences for the most serious of the individual offences committed. The second limb considers whether the effect of the sentence on the offender is crushing and not in keeping with his past record and his future prospects.

## The sentence

36     I now turn to the facts of the present case and the application of the above sentencing framework. The _first step_ is to identify the level of harm caused by the offence and the level of culpability of the offender.

#### Harm

37     In the present case, the victim had suffered a right femur shaft open fracture, a right lateral femur condyle avulsion fracture, right distal fibula and calcaneal fractures, a right open subtalar dislocation, a right cuboid and 2nd metatarsal base fracture as well as a right ankle degloving injury. In essence, the victim had suffered multiple fractures requiring multiple surgical intervention as set out in the 9 December 2020 TTSH medical report prepared by Dr Daniel Hap. The victim was hospitalised in TTSH from 21 days and was given 35 days of hospitalisation leave.

38     Based on the nature of injuries suffered by the victim, the surgical procedures he underwent, his period of hospitalisation as well as medical leave, I agreed with the Prosecution that the level of harm was within the moderate range as defined in _Sue Chang_ at \[87(b)\]. I disagreed with the Defence’s position that the harm fell within the lower end of moderate range as it was uncertain if the injuries were more of a permanent nature as the victim had returned to Malaysia for further follow-up. I agreed with the Prosecution that there was no conjunctive requirement for the injuries to be of a more permanent nature and involving more complex fractures/dislocation which necessitate some surgical procedures with a moderate period of hospitalisation and/or medical leave.

#### Culpability

39     As for the accused’s level of culpability, I agreed with the Prosecution and the Defence that it was low as the accident occurred out of a momentary lapse of attention when he failed to keep a proper lookout ahead and collided into the victim as he made the right turn when the traffic light was green only. The accused ought to have checked for oncoming traffic coming from the opposite direction before he made the discretionary right turn or waited for the green right turn arrow to come on before executing the right turn.

40     The Defence had sought to reduce the accused’s culpability by attributing some of the blame on the victim by arguing that he was speeding and drink driving at the material time. Although the victim has been dealt with for the offence of drink driving, the fact remains that he had the right of way as he was proceeding straight along Hougang Avenue 8. I noted from the in-car camera footage provided by the witness, the victim’s headlamp was lit when he crossed the junction. There was no evidence that he was in breach of other road traffic rules or regulations. Further, there was no objective evidence of the victim’s actual speed at the material time as he crossed the junction.

41     It was the Defence’s position that the footage clearly showed that the victim was going at a high speed as shown by the impact of the accident. It was the Defence’s position that had the victim not been drinking and driving or speeding, he would have stopped, slowed down or swerved to manage or control his motorcycle to avoid the said collision. I agreed with the Prosecution’s submissions that this proposition was speculative and did not detract from the fact that the victim had right of way. Furthermore, from the in-vehicle footage provided by the witness, it was evident that the accused had accelerated as he made the right turn when the traffic light was green only. Under such circumstances, the victim would not have had sufficient time to react to the accused’s vehicle coming within his path of travel. The impact of the collision caused the victim who can be considered as a vulnerable victim to be flung over the car and he landed a short distance away.

42     The _second step_ is to identify the applicable indicative sentencing range in the sentencing matrix. Based on the _Sue Chang_ sentencing framework where the level of culpability is low and the harm moderate, the appropriate range of sentence would be a fine or a custodial sentence of up to four months. The sentencing judge should be alive to possibility of imposing such a combination of punishments so as to properly take into account the full sentencing range prescribed by Parliament.

43     In the present case, due to the seriousness of injuries suffered by the victim, the surgical procedures he underwent as well as both his period of hospitalisation as well as medical leave, I agreed with the Prosecution that the custodial threshold had been crossed. I disagreed with the Defence that the imposition maximum would serve as a sufficiently strong deterrence to the accused. By seeking to attribute some blame on the victim although he had the right of way and had travelled with his headlights on, this shows that the accused was not genuinely remorseful for his actions.

44     The _third step_ is to identify the appropriate starting point within the indicative sentencing range. This is to be informed by the level of harm caused by the offence and the level of the offender’s culpability. In the present case, in view of the degree of harm caused, I was of the view that the starting point should be two months imprisonment.

45     The _fourth step_ is to make the necessary adjustments to the starting point to take into account the offender-specific aggravating and mitigating factors. In the present case, I considered the fact that the accused had pleaded guilty to the charge, immediate assistance was rendered to the victim through his son and he had cooperated with the authorities. I further considered that there were no culpability enhancing factors in the present case. Accordingly, I was of the view that a downward calibration to four weeks’ imprisonment was warranted in view of these mitigating factors.

46     I disagreed with the Defence’s position that the maximum fine of $5,000 was appropriate in view of the seriousness of the harm caused as the victim suffered multiple fractures which required multiple surgical procedure, his substantial period of hospitalisation as well as hospitalisation leave to aid in his recovery. I did not place any weight to the Defence’s submissions on his personal and familial circumstances that were set out in his mitigation. It is trite that financial difficulties are not to be regarded as mitigating factors, save for exceptional circumstances: see _Lai Oei Mui Jenny v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[1993\] 2 SLR(R) 406</span> at \[10\]. I also placed no weight on the Defence’s submission that his imprisonment would cause hardship to his family. In _Public Prosecutor v Mohammed Liton Mohammed Syeed Mallik_ <span class="citation">\[2008\] 1 SLR(R) 601</span> at \[98\], the Court of Appeal stated that “in the absence of very exceptional or extreme circumstances, little, if any, weight should be attached to the fact that the accused’s family will suffer if the accused is imprisoned for a substantial period of time.”

47     The _fifth step_ was not applicable in the present case as the accused faced a single charge.

#### Disqualification order

48     In deciding on the appropriate period of disqualification, I was mindful that the disqualification order and the sentence imposed are not mutually compensatory.

49     In determining the appropriate length of the disqualification order, I was guided by the approach in the recent case of _Kwan Weiguang v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[2022\] SGHC 121</span> (“_Kwan_”). Although Aedit Abdullah J dealt with an appeal against a disqualification order of 15 months that was imposed on the appellant for an offence of dangerous driving under s 64(1) and punishable under s 64(2C)(_a_) of the RTA, the factors considered are relevant to the present case. He held at \[59\] and \[61\] that the objective of the disqualification order is as follow:

> A driving disqualification order combines three sentencing objectives: punishment, protection of the public and deterrence (_Edwin s/o Suse Nathen v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[2013\] 4 SLR 1139</span> (“_Edwin Nathen_”) at \[13\]). Often, due to the limited range of fines in the punishment provision, the impact of a disqualification order is likely to be felt much more acutely than any marginal increase in the quantum of the fine (see Edwin Nathen at \[13\])…

> 61    A disqualification order also serves to remove the privilege to drive from those who have abused it, and this also reinforces the notion of shared usage of the roads. It must be remembered that driving is an inherently dangerous activity. The licence to drive is a privilege accorded to persons who, through a series of properly administered tests, have demonstrated that they are capable of meeting the standards expected of a reasonably competent driver (_Jali bin Mohd Yunos v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[2014\] 4 SLR 1059</span> at \[36\]). The former Minister for Home Affairs, Prof S Jayakumar, had expressed the following view which reinforces this notion (see Singapore Parliamentary Debates, Official Report (28 March 1990) vol 55 at col 960): “… we must get every driver in Singapore to note that when he is issued a licence, it is in fact a very special privilege and it is granted on condition that he drives in a responsible manner bearing in mind the interest of others.”

50     In _Kwan_ at \[65\] to \[71\], the relevant and material factors when determining the period of disqualification are:

> (a)     Circumstances of the commission of the offence;

> (b)     Continued ability to drive and attitude towards other road users.

51     In the present case, the accident occurred when the accused failed to keep a proper lookout ahead and collided into the victim when he encroached into the victim’s path of travel as he made the right turn when the traffic light was green only. The accused ought to have checked for oncoming traffic coming from the opposite direction before he made the discretionary right turn or waited for the green right turn arrow to come on before executing the right turn. Although the accident had occurred at 12:52am, the victim’s presence would have been visible to the accused as the former was riding with his headlamp on.

52     In addition, there was a fair degree of potential harm, considering the conditions at the material time. Although the traffic volume at about 12.52am at the signalised junction of Hougang Avenue 8 was described in the Statement of Facts as light, it was evident from the footage that the road traffic was not negligible. It is foreseeable that as he made the right turn when the traffic light was green only, he could have posed a danger to other road users who were travelling in the same direction as the victim as well as to others in the vicinity of the junction.

53     It was clear that in the present case it was within the public’s interest to remove such a driver from the roads for a substantial period of time. Hence, I was of the view that the minimum disqualification period of five years with effect from the date of release agreed to by both the Prosecution and the Defence was appropriate as there were no special reasons before me not to make the order or to order a period less than the specified period of five years.

54     All things considered, I was of the view that the sentence of four weeks’ imprisonment and a disqualification from holding or obtaining all classes of driving licences for a period of five years in respect of DAC 9207566-2021 was just and appropriate in the circumstances.
